text.p: Gold drifted lower on Thursday afternoon as the market came to grips with comments by the U.S. central bank head suggesting interest rates may soon rise.
But prices remained above the psychological $350 an ounce range, and dealers said the market was not ready to rule out the upside in coming days.
Highly visible speculative buying out of New York's Comex market has buffeted the market this week and helped lift gold prices on Wednesday from a London close of $348.70/$349.20.
A repeat of such volatility was still seen as a possibility in coming days, dealers said.
"It's not over yet. Today Europe came in strong and New York put it under pressure rather than the other way around. But no one expected the fund buying yesterday," a dealer said.

Gold had registered little immediate reaction to comments by U.S. Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan which signalled the Fed may raise interest rates at next week's policy-making session for the first time in two years.
Bullion fixed at $352.00 an ounce shortly after his comments, compared to $352.70 in the morning.
But prices subsequently dipped towards $350.50 an ounce while the dollar surged and the stock market dropped, before stabilising.
A rise in interest rates is traditionally considered bearish for the gold market, in part because it would increase the cost of holding on to the metal.
"I can't believe that the kind of rate rise that has been discussed would be that damaging for gold," said analyst Tony Warwick-Ching of CRU International.
"On the other hand, if it caused the dollar to gain much against the yen that would be more worrying. The weaker yen has been bad for gold in Japan," he added.
Silver was little changed at $5.19/$5.21, down just one cent from Wednesday's London close. It was watching gold.
The other white metals were off highs as players took profits following good gains in platinum and palladium on Wednesday and early Thursday, dealers said.
Platinum was off its highs at $379.00/$380.00, but it was still up $2.75 from Wednesday's London close.
Palladium similarly was below the days' highs at $150.25/$151.25. But it was still up $3.75 from Thursday on buiying believed to be on behalf of a fund.
